hook.text: You tap glass and your phone responds. No buttons, no mechanical parts. How does it know where you touched?

buildup.text: Beneath the glass is a grid of tiny electrical sensors. Your finger disrupts their electrical field.

discovery.text: This is called capacitive touch. Human skin conducts electricity, so the screen detects your fingertip.

twist.text: That's why gloves don't work on touchscreens. The fabric blocks the electrical connection.

climax.text: Modern screens track ten fingers simultaneously and detect pressure levels for different interactions.

punchline.text: Touchscreens work because your body conducts electricity.

quiz.question: Why don't regular gloves work on capacitive touchscreens?
options: Fabric blocks the electrical connection from your skin
The screen can't detect color through gloves
